moves.1. Nf3 Nc6:
I always thought that this was a weak choice.

Interesting enough, Stockfish 9, on a deep search, gives 1... d5 2. d4 Bf5 3. c4 e6 4. Qb3 Nc6 5. Qxb7 Nb4 6. Na3 Rb8 7. Qxa7 Ra8 8. Qb7 Rb8 9. Qa7 as equal, which is maybe why the program favors 1. e4.   However, looking at the position, it doesn't seem equal.
moves.2. d4 d5 3. c4: Strangely enough, Stockfish 9 prefers 3. e3 Bf5 4. Bb5 e6 5. c4.
moves.4... Nf6 5. Bg5: And once again, 5. e3 is better.
moves.6. e3: Stronger is 6. Qb3 a5 7. a3 a4 8. Qc2 Bxc3+ 9. Qxc3.
moves.6... Bd7 7. Bd3: For reasons that aren't clear to me, Stockfish 9 thinks that 7. cxd5 exd5 8. Bd3 is much better.
moves.8... gxf6 9. O-O: Stockfish 9 thinks that White is winning after 9. cxd5 exd5 10. Nh4 Ne7 11. Qf3 Rg8 12. a3 Bg4 13. Qxf6.
moves.18. Nxc6 bxc6 19. Bxe4 Qd6: Here White started paying attention to sacrifices on g3.
moves.20... f5: Doesn't help at all.  Instead Black can play 20... Kd8 or 20... Kd7.
moves.21. Bxc6 Kd8 22. Rb8+: White can do better with 22. d5, threatening to open of the center files.
moves.22... Ke7 23. Rxg8 Rxg8 24. Qb4:
White chooses to just win the ending.

Both 24. Re1 and 24. Qc4 are a little stronger .
moves.24... f4 25. Re1 fxg3 26. fxg3 h5 27. d5: This offer a trade is not bad, because the pawns will win.
moves.30... Kf8 31. Kg2: Maybe a little better is 31. Bg6.
moves.40... Rf2+ 41. Kc3 Rxh2: This the the final nail in the coffin.
moves.42. Rh4+: Things are easy after the rook trade.
moves.42... Rxh4 43. gxh4 Kg7 44. b5 Kh6 45. a: White's pawn majority can't be stopped.
Missing Mate in 4 with  52. Bf3 Kf5 (52... Kh4 53. Qf4+) 53. Kd4 Kg5 54. Qe6 Kf4 55. Qg4#
moves.52... Kg4 53. Kd4: Also missing mate in 4: 53. Qe5 Kh4 54. Qf4+ Kh5 (54... Kh3 55. Qg5) 55. Qg3 Kh6 56. Qg6#.
